title: 9  Homework 8: Text Data
text:
9.1 Purpose
The purpose of this homework is to give you several opportunities to practice functions and tools taught in Lecture 8 using R. Once completed, submit both your quarto document (.qmd) and the rendered HTML file.
Failure to submit a properly rendered HTML file will result in a grade of 0 for this homework.

title: 9  Homework 8: Text Data
text:
9.7 Task 4 (1 pt)
Using case_when() and the data you created in Task 2, create a new column or variable called rural_agency using the R chunk below. Save the resulting table (data frame) into your R environment (name it however you want but make sure it follows best practice). Make sure to print a sample of the data below too.
For your case_when(): rural_agency should be equals to “Rural Housing Service” if program area is either single or multifamily housing. rural_agency should be equals to “Rural Utilities Service” if program area is water and environmental, telecommunications, or electric. rural_agency should be equals to “Rural Business-Cooperative Service” if program area is Business programs.

# Place your script below:
task4_data <- task2_data |>
  mutate(rural_agency = case_when(
    program_area == 'Single Family Housing' ~ 'Rural Housing Service',
    program_area == 'Multifamily Housing' ~ 'Rural Housing Service', 
    program_area == 'Water and Environmental' ~ 'Rural Utilities Service',
    program_area == 'Telecommunications Programs' ~ 'Rural Utilities Service', 
    program_area == 'Electric Programs' ~ 'Rural Utilities Service',
    program_area == 'Business Programs' ~ 'Rural Business-Cooperative Service',
  ))

title: 9  Homework 8: Text Data
text:
9.8 Task 5 (0.5 pt)
The code below creates two tables (employees_2023, employees_2024) in your R environment.
Make sure you run the code below before moving forward. Read the two tables accordingly as well.

employees_2023 <- data.frame(
  EmployeeID = c(1, 2, 3),
  Name = c("Alice", "Bob", "Charlie"),
  Department = c("HR", "IT", "Finance"),
  Salary = c(50000, 60000, 55000)
)

employees_2024 <- data.frame(
  EmployeeID = c(4, 5),
  Name = c("Diana", "Eve"),
  Department = c("HR", "IT"),
  Salary = c(52000, 61000)
)

glimpse(employees_2023)

Rows: 3
Columns: 4
$ EmployeeID <dbl> 1, 2, 3
$ Name       <chr> "Alice", "Bob", "Charlie"
$ Department <chr> "HR", "IT", "Finance"
$ Salary     <dbl> 50000, 60000, 55000

glimpse(employees_2024)

Rows: 2
Columns: 4
$ EmployeeID <dbl> 4, 5
$ Name       <chr> "Diana", "Eve"
$ Department <chr> "HR", "IT"
$ Salary     <dbl> 52000, 61000


Each table (data frame) has the columns: EmployeeID, Name, Department, and Salary.

employees_2023 contains data for employees in 2023.
employees_2024 contains data for new hires in 2024.

Using the code chunk below, bind the two data frames together to create a table that is essentially a master list of all employees across both years. Save this data into your R environment and name it appropriately based on best practices. Make sure to print the data below too.

# Place your script below:
task5_data <- bind_rows(employees_2023, employees_2024)

head(task5_data)

  EmployeeID    Name Department Salary
1          1   Alice         HR  50000
2          2     Bob         IT  60000
3          3 Charlie    Finance  55000
4          4   Diana         HR  52000
5          5     Eve         IT  61000

title: 9  Homework 8: Text Data
text:
9.9 Task 6 (0.5 pt)
The code below creates two tables (group_a, group_b) in your R environment.
Make sure you run the code below before moving forward. Read the two tables accordingly as well.

group_a <- data.frame(
  ParticipantID = c("A1", "A2", "A3"),
  Age = c(25, 30, 35),
  Score = c(88, 92, 85)
)

group_b <- data.frame(
  ParticipantID = c("B1", "B2", "B3"),
  Age = c(25, 30, 40),
  Score = c(90, 89, 95)
)

group_a

  ParticipantID Age Score
1            A1  25    88
2            A2  30    92
3            A3  35    85

group_b

  ParticipantID Age Score
1            B1  25    90
2            B2  30    89
3            B3  40    95


You are conducting a study and have collected data from two groups of participants, group_a and group_b, on their age and test scores. Each data frame has columns: ParticipantID, Age, and Score.

group_a is a table (data frame) that contains data for participants in Group A.
group_b is a table (data frame) that contains data for participants in Group B.

Bind the two tables (data frames) to create a single data set of all participants using the R chunk below. Save this data into your R environment and name it appropriately based on best practices. Make sure to print the data below too.

# Place your script below:
task6_data <- bind_rows(group_a, group_b)
head(task6_data)

  ParticipantID Age Score
1            A1  25    88
2            A2  30    92
3            A3  35    85
4            B1  25    90
5            B2  30    89
6            B3  40    95

title: 9  Homework 8: Text Data
text:
9.10 Task 7 (1 pt)
The code blow creates a table (data frame) called address_df. Run the code below before proceeding forward and make sure to pay attention to the printed data:

address_df <- data.frame(street = c("123 Main St", "456 Oak Ave", "789 Pine Rd"),
                         city = c("Springfield", "Riverdale", "Greendale"),
                         state = c("IL", "NY", "CA"))
address_df

       street        city state
1 123 Main St Springfield    IL
2 456 Oak Ave   Riverdale    NY
3 789 Pine Rd   Greendale    CA


Use str_c() within the R chunk below to combine the three variables from address_df into a full address, formatted as “Street, City, State.” Name this new variable/column full_address.

# Place your script below:
address_df |>
  mutate(full_address = str_c(street, city, state, sep = ", "))

       street        city state                 full_address
1 123 Main St Springfield    IL 123 Main St, Springfield, IL
2 456 Oak Ave   Riverdale    NY   456 Oak Ave, Riverdale, NY
3 789 Pine Rd   Greendale    CA   789 Pine Rd, Greendale, CA

title: 9  Homework 8: Text Data
text:
9.11 Task 8 (1 pt)
The code blow creates a table (data frame) called pricing_table. Run the code below before proceeding forward and make sure to pay attention to the printed data:

pricing_table <- data.frame(product = c("Apples", "Bananas", "Cherries"),
                            prices = c("1.20", "0.80", "2.50"))
pricing_table 

   product prices
1   Apples   1.20
2  Bananas   0.80
3 Cherries   2.50


Use str_c() to create a variable called pricing_sentence using R chunk below. str_c() should produce a single sentence for each item, formatted as “ItemName costs $Price.” For example, the pricing_sentence value for the first row should state “Apples costs $1.20”.

# Place your script below:
pricing_table |>
  mutate(pricing_sentence = str_c(product, " costs $", prices))

   product prices     pricing_sentence
1   Apples   1.20   Apples costs $1.20
2  Bananas   0.80  Bananas costs $0.80
3 Cherries   2.50 Cherries costs $2.50

title: 9  Homework 8: Text Data
text:
9.12 Task 9 (1 pt)
Using pricing_table (data from task 8), use str_glue() to create a variable called pricing_sentence_v2 using R chunk below. str_glue() should also produce a single sentence for each item, formatted as “ItemName costs $Price before taxes.” For example, the pricing_sentence_v2 value for the first row should state “Apples costs $1.20 before taxes”.

# Place your script below:
pricing_table |>
  mutate(pricing_sentence = str_glue("{product} costs ${prices} before taxes"))

   product prices                  pricing_sentence
1   Apples   1.20   Apples costs $1.20 before taxes
2  Bananas   0.80  Bananas costs $0.80 before taxes
3 Cherries   2.50 Cherries costs $2.50 before taxes

9.14 Task 10 (1 pt)
Using news_headlines and the R chunk below, create a topic indicator variable to detect any crime-related topic or word of your choosing. Then only print a sample of your data that contains the key word of your choosing. Make sure you detect at least one matching row with your keyword (otherwise, pick another keyword).

# Place your script below:
news_headlines_v2 <- news_headlines |>
  mutate(robbery_mentioned = str_detect(headline, regex("robbery", ignore_case = TRUE)))

title: 9  Homework 8: Text Data
text:
9.15 Task 11 (1 pt)
Before proceeding, make sure to run the following script and read the printed data:

employees <- data.frame(
  name = c("Tom", "Jerry", "Anna", "Laura", "Nick"),
  years_experience = c(1, 3, 7, 5, 2)
)
employees

   name years_experience
1   Tom                1
2 Jerry                3
3  Anna                7
4 Laura                5
5  Nick                2


employees is a table (data frame) with information about employees’ years of experience. Use case_when() in the R chunk below to create a new column experience_level that classifies each employee according to this breakdown:

Less than 2 years: "Junior"
2 to 5 years: "Mid-level"
More than 5 years: "Senior"


# Place your script below:
employees |>
  mutate(experience_level = case_when(
    years_experience < 2 ~ "Junior",
    between(years_experience, 2, 5) ~ "Mid-level",
    years_experience > 5 ~ "Senior"
  ))

   name years_experience experience_level
1   Tom                1           Junior
2 Jerry                3        Mid-level
3  Anna                7           Senior
4 Laura                5        Mid-level
5  Nick                2        Mid-level

title: 9  Homework 8: Text Data
text:
9.16 Task 12 (0.5 pt)
Before proceeding, make sure to run the following script and read the printed data:

movie_years <- data.frame(movie = c("Inception", "The Matrix", "Titanic"),
                          release_year = c("2010", "1999", "1997"))
movie_years

       movie release_year
1  Inception         2010
2 The Matrix         1999
3    Titanic         1997


Using str_c() or str_glue() within the R chunk below with the movie_years table (data frame), create a variable/column called movie_year where each entry includes the movie title then the release year in parentheses (e.g., “Inception (2010)”).

# Place your script below:

movie_years |>
  mutate(movie_year = str_glue("{movie} ({release_year})"))

       movie release_year        movie_year
1  Inception         2010  Inception (2010)
2 The Matrix         1999 The Matrix (1999)
3    Titanic         1997    Titanic (1997)

title: 8  Homework 7: Joins
text:
8.4 Task 1-3 Data
Before proceeding, run the two R chunks below and pay attention to the outputs and how each printed table (data frames) looks like:

# Code that creates then prints df1
df1 <- data.frame(
  ID = c(1, 2, 3),
  Name = c("Alice", "Bob", "Charlie"),
  Age = c(24, 30, 22)
)

df1

  ID    Name Age
1  1   Alice  24
2  2     Bob  30
3  3 Charlie  22



# Code that creates then prints df1
df2 <- data.frame(
  ID = c(2, 3, 4),
  City = c("New York", "Los Angeles", "Chicago"),
  Salary = c(60000, 70000, 80000)
)
df2

  ID        City Salary
1  2    New York  60000
2  3 Los Angeles  70000
3  4     Chicago  80000

title: 8  Homework 7: Joins
text:
8.5 Task 1 (0.5 pt)
Using df1 and df2 from Task 1-3 data, perform a left_join() on ID and print the resulting table (data frame) below. Make sure df1 appears first before df2 inside left_join().

# Place your script below:
left_join(df1, df2, join_by(ID))

  ID    Name Age        City Salary
1  1   Alice  24        <NA>     NA
2  2     Bob  30    New York  60000
3  3 Charlie  22 Los Angeles  70000

title: 8  Homework 7: Joins
text:
8.6 Task 2 (0.5 pt)
Using df1 and df2 from Task 1-3 data, perform a inner_join() on ID and print the resulting table (data frame) below:

# Place your script below:
inner_join(df1, df2, join_by(ID))

  ID    Name Age        City Salary
1  2     Bob  30    New York  60000
2  3 Charlie  22 Los Angeles  70000

title: 8  Homework 7: Joins
text:
8.7 Task 3 (1 pt)
In 1-5 sentences, describe in your own words the difference in output between the left and inner joined data between df1 and df2 below. Essentially, answer the following: what is left_join() doing compared to inner_join()?
Your response: left_join() appends data from the 2nd data frame (if there is a match) to the 1st data frame and if there are no matches, new column fields are left blank (NAs). inner_join() only keeps rows where there is a match between the two data frames, thereby excluding non-matching rows.

title: 8  Homework 7: Joins
text:
8.8 Task 4 Data
Before proceeding, run the two R chunks below and pay attention to the outputs and how each printed table (data frames) looks like:

# Code that creates then prints departments
departments <- data.frame(
  DeptID = c(101, 102, 103),
  DeptName = c("HR", "Finance", "IT"),
  Location = c("Building A", "Building B", "Building C")
)
departments

  DeptID DeptName   Location
1    101       HR Building A
2    102  Finance Building B
3    103       IT Building C



# Code that creates then prints employees
employees <- data.frame(
  EmpID = c(1, 2, 3),
  DeptID = c(101, 104, 103),
  EmpName = c("John", "Jane", "Tom")
)
employees

  EmpID DeptID EmpName
1     1    101    John
2     2    104    Jane
3     3    103     Tom

title: 8  Homework 7: Joins
text:
8.9 Task 4 (0.5 pt)
Using the Task 4 data sets, perform a left_join() on DeptID. Make sure departments appears first before employees inside left_join(). Print the resulting table (data frame) below.

# Place your script below:
left_join(departments, employees, join_by(DeptID))

  DeptID DeptName   Location EmpID EmpName
1    101       HR Building A     1    John
2    102  Finance Building B    NA    <NA>
3    103       IT Building C     3     Tom

title: 8  Homework 7: Joins
text:
8.10 Task 5 (0.5 pt)
Describe in detail why some columns or variables in the table (data frame) you generated under Task 4 have missing data (NA).
Your response:

Some fields in the resulting data frame may have missing data (NA) because not all DeptID values in the departments data frame have matching rows in the employees data frame.

title: 8  Homework 7: Joins
text:
8.11 Task 6 (0.5 pt)
Using the Task 4 data sets, perform a left_join() on DeptID. This time, make sure employees appears first before departments inside left_join(). Print the resulting table (data frame) below.

# Place your script below:
left_join(employees, departments, join_by(DeptID))

  EmpID DeptID EmpName DeptName   Location
1     1    101    John       HR Building A
2     2    104    Jane     <NA>       <NA>
3     3    103     Tom       IT Building C

title: 8  Homework 7: Joins
text:
8.12 Task 7 (1 pt)
Explain in detail why the table outputs for Task 4 and Task 6 are different or the same. In this case, does the order matter at all for left_join()?
Your response: The order matters. The difference arises because the order of the data frames determines which data frame’s rows are fully preserved in the output (i.e., rows from the first data frame fed into left_join), then columns/variables from the 2nd data frame is then added to the first data frame. Unmatched data are then assigned NAs with respect to the additional variables or columns added from the 2nd data frame. Another framing: in Task 4, we assign an employee to each department, while in Task 6, we assign a department to each employee.

Explain in detail why the table outputs for Task 8 and Task 9 are different or the same. In this case, does the order matter at all for inner_join()?

title: 8  Homework 7: Joins
text:
8.19 Task 13 (1 pt)
In detail, what does the join you performed in Task 12 achieve? Explain the join and output in detail. What type of join did you perform (i.e., filtering, mutating)?
Your response: Performed a filtering join via semi_join() as semi_join() doesn’t add additional variables. In semi_join(), rows from the first data frame are only kept if and only if their join key(s) exists or have a match in the 2nd data frame.

title: 6  Homework 5: File Reading
text:
6.5 Background information on Task 1 Data
The RuralDevelopmentInvestments.csv is an extract from USDA Rural Development’s dashboard found on https://www.rd.usda.gov/rural-data-gateway/rural-investments
fiscal_year is the fiscal year, ranges from 2012-2024 (Note: 2024 is only partial data)
state_name includes the state name or territory name
program_area is the USDA program area that made the investment
total_investment_dollars is the total USDA investment made by Rural Development (one of USDA’s agencies)
number_investments is the total investment counts made by Rural Development (one of USDA’s agencies)
svi_investments is the total USDA investment that went towards communities that are considered socially vulnerable
Make sure to understand the data before attempting any additional tasks.

title: 6  Homework 5: File Reading
text:
6.11 Background information on Task 5 Data
The cancer_mortality.xlsx file is a subset, and both an abbreviated and manipulated version of data found in https://statecancerprofiles.cancer.gov/map/map.withimage.php
Basic information about the variables you loaded is as follows:
County contains the county name along with its state name
CountyFIPS containsthe county FIPS/GEOID code for the county
RuralUrbanStatus identifies the rural or urban status of the county
DeathRate is the overall death (mortality) rate for all cancers types within that county (deaths per 100,000 population)

title: 5  Homework 4: dplyr
text:
5.3 Background information on rural_development_investments
This data is an extract from USDA Rural Development’s dashboard found on https://www.rd.usda.gov/rural-data-gateway/rural-investments
fiscal_year is the fiscal year, ranges from 2012-2024 (Note: 2024 is only partial data)
state_name includes the state name or territory name
program_area is the USDA program area that made the investment
total_investment_dollars is the total USDA investment made by Rural Development (one of USDA’s agencies)
number_investments is the total investment counts made by Rural Development (one of USDA’s agencies)
svi_investments is the total USDA investment that went towards communities that are considered socially vulnerable
Make sure to study the data before attempting the tasks below:

Documentation: https://dplyr.tidyverse.org/reference/starwars.html

msleep

Documentation: https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/msleep.html


After picking the data set, you need to create and run R code that will do the following:

Load the data into your R environment.
Print (and understand) sample data.
Using the data you picked, create any visualization you want to create (at least one is required). Please stick to one of the data visualization types you were taught in Exercise2.qmd

Include your solution into the subsequent code chunk below. Note: you may include all the required code into the single code chunk below, or you may also create and use additional R code chunks. It is up to you!
Important Note: It is possible that the data viz you create for this task may look odd (e.g., everything is so small due to way too many categorical variables). That is fine. As long as your underlying code is correct and makes sense, you will get full credit. Feel free to play around and create additional data viz as practice below too! At least one is required.

# Place your code here (and/or below within the same chunk as needed)
data(msleep)
head(msleep)

# A tibble: 6 × 11
  name    genus vore  order conservation sleep_total sleep_rem sleep_cycle awake

# Many combinations you can pick from. But here's one I did:
ggplot(data = msleep, 
       mapping = aes(x = vore, y = sleep_total)) +
  geom_boxplot()
